intro: Plectrelminthus caudatus var. trilobatus, commonly known as the three-lobed bladderwort, is a rare aquatic plant belonging to the family Lentibulariaceae. It is characterized by its small, bladder-like structures that trap small aquatic organisms, aiding in its nutrient acquisition. The plant typically grows in shallow, freshwater habitats such as ponds and ditches. Its leaves are usually divided into three lobes, giving it its specific epithet "trilobatus." Due to its limited distribution and specialized habitat requirements, it is considered a vulnerable species in many regions.
